feed.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin

entry.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin
entry.summary:
The discussion initiated by AdamISZ/waxwing raises intriguing points regarding the implications of a potential Elliptic Curve Discrete Logarithm Problem (ECDLP) breaker on taproot, a privacy and efficiency improvement proposal for Bitcoin. Specifically, it delves into the scenario where taproot is modified to solely permit script-path spending, thereby excluding key-path spendings. This alteration centers around an honest keyholder generating a public key Q by adding a NUMS internal key P_N to the hash of the concatenation of P_N and a script S, multiplied by the generator G. The critical observation made is that even if an ECDLP breaker could resolve the discrete logarithm of Q, the mandated commitment to a specific public key P_2 via hashing constrains the attacker. This constraint necessitates the selection of P_2 before its hash operation, which theoretically mitigates the advantage of knowing the full private key corresponding to Q.
The conversation further contemplates the broader implications of such cryptographic vulnerabilities, especially in light of quantum computing advances. A hypothetical, yet profound, consideration is posited about the future where a quantum algorithm might efficiently compute SHA2 preimages, challenging current cryptographic assumptions underpinning Bitcoin's security model. This speculative inquiry underscores the necessity of contemplating not only the immediate but also potentially paradigm-shifting threats to blockchain security protocols.
AdamISZ/waxwing's message, circulated within the Bitcoin Development Mailing List, embodies a deep technical examination of taproot's resilience against emerging cryptographic breakthroughs. It illustrates a proactive approach to cryptographic security, emphasizing the importance of anticipating and preparing for future challenges that could undermine the integrity of blockchain systems. Through this dialogue, the community is encouraged to engage with and scrutinize the foundational assumptions ensuring the security of digital assets in an evolving technological landscape.
